summary: When Jon had been a boy at Winterfell, his hero had been the Young Dragon, the boy king who had conquered Dorne at the age of...
body:
When Jon had been a boy at Winterfell, his hero had been the Young Dragon, the boy king who had conquered Dorne at the age of fourteen.

Jon’s hero was one of his ancestors (and he didn’t even know it). How cute is that?

reblog.comment:
When Jon had been a boy at Winterfell, his hero had been the Young Dragon, the boy king who had conquered Dorne at the age of fourteen.

Jon’s hero was one of his ancestors (and he didn’t even know it). How cute is that?

summary: My dearest Jon take your woman, Ghost,Arya, Bran and Gendry to Esoss and let Lady Stark to save the North alone.
body:
My dearest Jon take your woman, Ghost,Arya, Bran and Gendry to Esoss and let Lady Stark to save the North alone.

She is a smart politician and can everything. She can save the North independence after defeat Night King 👏🏽👏🏽👏🏽 Probably makes big conversation and merry with Night King and finally her dream comes true. She became a queen 😂😍😂😍

question: Ship ask: jonsa
answer:
vomit / don’t ship / okay / cute / adorable / perfect / beyond flawless / hot damn / screaming and crying / i will ship them in hell

I can’t say this with 100% certainty but if I enjoyed Jon’s character, this might be one of my lowkey Sansa ships. You definitely have to like both Jon and Sansa because the fandom is really about the both of them. Unfortunately, I only care about Sansa.

summary: What can George R.R. Martin’s original outline tell us about the ending of Game of Thrones?
title: What can George R.R. Martin’s original outline tell us about the ending of Game of Thrones?
excerpt: It's pretty common knowledge that, before George R.R. Martin published A Game of Thrones way back in 1996, he sent a three-page letter to his publisher ...
description:
“Speaking of incest, Martin’s outline also addresses the issue of Jon’s secret Targaryen identity, saying that Jon and Arya’s passion for each other will “torment” the both of them “until the secret of Jon’s true parentage is finally revealed in the last book.”

Wait, what? Here’s to hoping that even THAT plan changed and this doesn’t mean we have to wait for Dream for book confirmation.

reblog.comment:
“Speaking of incest, Martin’s outline also addresses the issue of Jon’s secret Targaryen identity, saying that Jon and Arya’s passion for each other will “torment” the both of them “until the secret of Jon’s true parentage is finally revealed in the last book.”

Wait, what? Here’s to hoping that even THAT plan changed and this doesn’t mean we have to wait for Dream for book confirmation.

Wait, what? Here’s to hoping that even THAT plan changed and this doesn’t mean we have to wait for Dream for book confirmation.

Wait, what? Here’s to hoping that even THAT plan changed and this doesn’t mean we have to wait for Dream for book confirmation.

blog.name: chitowngirl-12
blog.title: Chicago Diva
blog.description: I'm a fan of Jon, the North, and the Starks.  Not a Jonsa, but an ally because they are nice, rational people unlike other parts of GOT fandom that will remain nameless.  (Apparently I'm also a sexist crazy person for having bad, ungood opinions about Daenerys Targaryen!  And I also set up alts and post anonymous comments and talk to myself on AO3...  Sarc off.  Yeah, fandom is pissing me off right now.)

tags: Overpowering Daenerys on the show was a bad idea
There is no reason why the Starks and Targs couldn't be allies
Jon is actually cunning and shows some skill at ruling in the books
Show Jon is nothing more than a pawn and servant
Jonerys would have been fine if it was a relationship of equals
summary: Answering a Whole Lot of Questions from a Daenerys Fan Part 3
title: Answering a Whole Lot of Questions from a Daenerys Fan Part 3
body:
In which I end the questions that @reddragonandwhitewolf is asking

Ned lied to Robert to keep his promise to his sister and protect HIS NEPHEW so Robert wouldn’t KILL HIM!

Yes!  This is the point I am trying to make!  It is a horrible thing for Robert to decide to kill a baby.  It is morally reprehensible!  However, Robert was well within his rights to do so.  There is no Geneva Convention, no Bill of Rights, no independent courts that could constrain Robert and tell him that killing a child because you are mad that a lady rejected you is a bad thing.

I’ve been married for 15 yrs, how old are you exactly?

In my 30s.  And I am trying to explain the political framework on the show, so I’m not sure why this is relevant.

She hasn’t done any of what you’re accusing her.

I’m not accusing her of anything.  I’m giving you a rundown of the powers a monarch has based on the legal framework and her own immense power.  The showrunners erred in making Dany so overpowered and making the Starks so weak.  They could have done scenarios where Dany and the Starks are equal allies or even powerful vassals like the Lannister-Tyrells.  However, that is not the scenario the show has gone with.  The Starks in general and Jon in specific have no leverage in the relationship.  They are completely at Daenerys’ mercy.

For all your claims of not shopping anyone, you sure do reblog Jonsa posts!

I don’t care who fucks who.  I’d be perfectly fine with JonxDaenerys as an endgame couple.  I wrote a fiction fixing the errors in Season 7 and presenting a more appealing endgame that is based on a JonxDany political marriage and a personal union.  I don’t like the show version of Jonerys.  I will probably write a post in a few weeks about how Jonerys could have been done better on the show.  

I don’t like the personal vitriol directed at Sansa fans, which I think is unfair.  They have a right to enjoy the show they way they wish.  They also tend to hate Season 7 of the show like I do and want the North to be independent.

No Jon fan I know would ever call him worthless or a toy, whether he’s a King or not.

I am a Jon fan, which is why I hate the character on the show.  They’ve done a hatchet job on him.  Jon has no redeeming qualities as a character.  He is a bad politician, a bad leader, and a bad military strategist.  Jon lost the Battle of the Bastards by getting played by Ramsay.  He makes piss poor political decisions.  He isn’t taken seriously by his enemies and his lords are disgruntled.  He gives away the North to Dany not for political gain but because she is nice and pretty and sad about losing her dragons.  Are you really telling me that Jon is going to suddenly morph into a great politician and strategist in Season 8?  That he is going to outsmart Cersei or find a clever way to defeat the Night King.  That seems highly unlikely given how the show’s plot is based on Jon doing stupid but honorable things and getting played by others.  Season 8 will likely be more of Jon in meaningless fight sequences where he is nearly defeated and needs to get bailed out and Jon doing stupid things that cost him men and allies or make Team Good Guys’ job harder.  That has been his role for the past two seasons and will continue to be his role in Season 8.  The writers don’t think that morally good characters can be interesting characters or brilliant politicians.  This is why they’ve chosen to use Jon as a pawn whose utter incompetence sets off the action and complicates the plot rather than allowing him to have victories.  Show!Jon is a pawn, a damsal in distress and a servant who obeys others and gets saved by others; he isn’t a hero who saves people, has wily plans, or wins battles.

tags: Yes Jon is a powerless servant on the show
summary: Answering a Whole Load of Questions from a Daenerys-Fan Part 1.
title: Answering a Whole Load of Questions from a Daenerys-Fan Part 1.
body:
Okay, so these are @ princess-from-another-galaxy and I don’t want to clog up to replies on someone else’s page.

have you ever been in a relationship???

Yes, but this isn’t relevant to the inquiry.  I think that you are looking at JonxDany like it is a 21st-century relationship, not a feudal one where Dany has absolute power over Jon.  Dany has the RIGHT as queen to order people around, execute people on a whim, and burn Winterfell to the ground.  She practically isn’t going to burn Winterfell to the ground, but it is still legally hers that she can do of as she wishes.

Moreover, Jon and the Starks have no leverage over the Targaryens.  The North is powerless in terms of military and economics and is about to be overrun by ice zombies.  There is no way for them to exert leverage over the Targaryens.  They are at Dany’s complete mercy.

why would the woman who ended slavery half way around the world and made such an impact for it that they call her breaker of chains, want slaves ??

Again, I think that you are looking at this from a 21st-century Western state where people have rights.  Under a feudal system, the king or queen technically has all the power and BEND THE KNEE does mean absolute subjugation.  L’etat, c’est moi means just that.  The entire power of government is imbued in one person who makes laws, enacts laws, and judges cases.  There is no written constitution, no separation of powers, no Bill of Rights, no independent courts, no federalism, no capitalism, etc.  The ruler holds all the land and has complete control over all the economic activity.  To open a market or plant certain crops or trade with certain people, a vassal had to get approval from the Crown and the Crown will grant a monopoly (i.e. the East Indies Company.)  Moreover, the Crown has a right to approve or reject marriage alliances.  We saw this right after Aegon’s Conquest with Argella’s forced marriage to Orys and the forced marriage of Torrhen’s daughter (which he and his sons protested.)  This is done to keep rebellious lords in line and to prevent lords from forming powerful blocs and alliances against the Crown.  A wise ruler would have never let Rickard Stark, Hoster Tully, and Jon Arryn get away with the marriages they were planning because it was clear they were preparing to act against the Crown.

Now, it is wise politics for the ruler to present a certain image and be liked so he/she doesn’t lead people to rebel, but absolute dicks can survive in the system as well.  The books give us Robert, who was good at being liked, but also Tywin, Walder Frey, and Roose Bolton.  If you are a savvy politician or control a strategic waterway, you can be a tyrant and rule with fear.  Tywin was a pretty horrible man but was able to survive at the pinnacle of power for decades.  He would have gotten away with everything if he was kinder to Tyrion and cultivated him.

Moreover, Jon and the Starks have no leverage over the Targaryens.  The North is powerless in terms of military and economics and is about to be overrun by ice zombies.  There is no way for them to exert leverage over the Targaryens.  They are at Dany’s complete mercy.

why would the woman who ended slavery half way around the world and made such an impact for it that they call her breaker of chains, want slaves ??

Again, I think that you are looking at this from a 21st-century Western state where people have rights.  Under a feudal system, the king or queen technically has all the power and BEND THE KNEE does mean absolute subjugation.  L’etat, c’est moi means just that.  The entire power of government is imbued in one person who makes laws, enacts laws, and judges cases.  There is no written constitution, no separation of powers, no Bill of Rights, no independent courts, no federalism, no capitalism, etc.  The ruler holds all the land and has complete control over all the economic activity.  To open a market or plant certain crops or trade with certain people, a vassal had to get approval from the Crown and the Crown will grant a monopoly (i.e. the East Indies Company.)  Moreover, the Crown has a right to approve or reject marriage alliances.  We saw this right after Aegon’s Conquest with Argella’s forced marriage to Orys and the forced marriage of Torrhen’s daughter (which he and his sons protested.)  This is done to keep rebellious lords in line and to prevent lords from forming powerful blocs and alliances against the Crown.  A wise ruler would have never let Rickard Stark, Hoster Tully, and Jon Arryn get away with the marriages they were planning because it was clear they were preparing to act against the Crown.

Now, it is wise politics for the ruler to present a certain image and be liked so he/she doesn’t lead people to rebel, but absolute dicks can survive in the system as well.  The books give us Robert, who was good at being liked, but also Tywin, Walder Frey, and Roose Bolton.  If you are a savvy politician or control a strategic waterway, you can be a tyrant and rule with fear.  Tywin was a pretty horrible man but was able to survive at the pinnacle of power for decades.  He would have gotten away with everything if he was kinder to Tyrion and cultivated him.

trail.content_raw:
Okay, so these are @ princess-from-another-galaxy and I don’t want to clog up to replies on someone else’s page.

have you ever been in a relationship???

Yes, but this isn’t relevant to the inquiry.  I think that you are looking at JonxDany like it is a 21st-century relationship, not a feudal one where Dany has absolute power over Jon.  Dany has the RIGHT as queen to order people around, execute people on a whim, and burn Winterfell to the ground.  She practically isn’t going to burn Winterfell to the ground, but it is still legally hers that she can do of as she wishes.

Moreover, Jon and the Starks have no leverage over the Targaryens.  The North is powerless in terms of military and economics and is about to be overrun by ice zombies.  There is no way for them to exert leverage over the Targaryens.  They are at Dany’s complete mercy.

Now, it is wise politics for the ruler to present a certain image and be liked so he/she doesn’t lead people to rebel, but absolute dicks can survive in the system as well.  The books give us Robert, who was good at being liked, but also Tywin, Walder Frey, and Roose Bolton.  If you are a savvy politician or control a strategic waterway, you can be a tyrant and rule with fear.  Tywin was a pretty horrible man but was able to survive at the pinnacle of power for decades.  He would have gotten away with everything if he was kinder to Tyrion and cultivated him.

Okay, so these are @ princess-from-another-galaxy and I don’t want to clog up to replies on someone else’s page.

blog.title: Fiction consumes me and reality is a distant dream

tags: a song of ice and fire
summary: Wow it really is hard these days to find  fans of the show on here that are neutral about everything. Is there anyone that...
body: Wow it really is hard these days to find fans of the show on here that are neutral about everything. Is there anyone that recognises characters’ flaws while still appreciating the multiple layers of the character? That root for some characters while still being irritated by some choices they make? That dislike some characters but really like some of the scenes they have? That don’t write a 1000 essay on roasting a character in order to prove another is more superior? That doesn’t trash a character and their fans to simply make a ship more valid? Because if their are fans like this then put your hands up so we can be excited about the new season without all this saltiness?

tags: Tyrion and the Hound as foils for Jon
summary: What's your take on Jon possibly being scarred or losing an eye?  The more I think about it especially in relation to Jonsa and...
question: What's your take on Jon possibly being scarred or losing an eye?  The more I think about it especially in relation to Jonsa and Sansa the more likely I think it will happen.  The shot at the end of season 6 where half of Jon's face is hidden in the shadows could be foreshadowing?  Also, Sansa's relationships with The Hound and Tyrion could be foreshadowing as well?
answer:
Dear nonny,

@rose-of-red-lake made a post on Jon losing an eye, where you can look up most of the foreshadowing here - and I agree. I think at least bookwise it is very likely that this will happen.

As for Jon as the beast and the foreshadowing of this. You are right in this as well: Tyrion and the Hound are foils for Jon as the Beast. Look up the exceptional metas by @lady-in-a-song, where she looks into this (part 1, part 2, part 3, part 4, part 5)

I’d also alert you to this ask I got with the excellent addition by @kellyvela.

So yes, to all of your questions!

Thanks for the ask!

summary: To touch up on your last Nonnie ask. We know they love doing things in 3s. First time Jon faced death he was suppose to be a...
question: To touch up on your last Nonnie ask. We know they love doing things in 3s. First time Jon faced death he was suppose to be a Stark after by Catelyn. Second time he essentially became one by Sansa and then by the North.  Though by gesture only and he still can't believe or embrace it.  The third time it will be official by Sansa:)
answer:
Hey, nonnie!

I’m not sure that D&D use the rule of three as much as to actually matter, what with their dislike of “themes” and all but yeah, I agree. There is room for that interpretation. Anyway, you want to look at it, I think there’s about 100% chance that Jon will end the series as Jon Stark and I for one couldn’t be more pleased! It’s what he’s wanted his whole life, after all. :))

Thanks for the comment!

blog.name: read-what-i-read
blog.title: My ao3 Recommendations
blog.description: archive of my favorite fics, story metas, writing tips, inspiration, and all things storytelling.

summary: Suck the Water in my Chest (Cross My Fingers and Hope for the Best) - callmejude - Game of Thrones (TV) [Archive of Our Own]
title: Suck the Water in my Chest (Cross My Fingers and Hope for the Best) - callmejude - Game of Thrones (TV) [Archive of Our Own]
excerpt: An Archive of Our Own, a project of the Organization for Transformative Works
description:
“You shared beds at the Wall?”

“No, I just mean —” Jon starts, before he notices Theon is smirking at him.

Jon feels abruptly light, and a laugh bursts surprised and genuine from his chest. Theon ducks his head, but Jon can see a hint of a smile still on his face as he lifts the rest of the bread to his mouth.

description:
“Did you see him?”

“See —?”

“Robb — please, did you — did you see Robb? When you were— after the end?”
